body:
`walletcreatefundedpsbt` has some interesting features that `sendtoaddress` and `sendmany` don't have:
* manual coin selection
* manual `feeRate`
* outputting a PSBT
* creating a transaction without broadcasting

At the same time `walletcreatefundedpsbt` can't broadcast a transaction, which is inconvenient for simple use cases.

This PR introduces a new `send` RPC method which creates a PSBT, signs it if possible and broadcasts it by default. If it can't sign all inputs, it outputs a PSBT. If `broadcast` is set to `false` it will return the transaction in both PSBT and hex format.

Because it uses a PSBT internally, it will much easier to add hardware wallet support to this method (see https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14912#issuecomment-510520757). In fact, this PR is loosely based on the `signersend` method I implemented in #15876.

I switched the `inputs` and `outputs` arguments to facilitate the simplest use case with automatic coin selection:

```sh
bitcoin-cli send '{"bc1....": 0.001}'
```

I made `locktime` just another option.

This paves the way for deprecating `sendtoaddress` and `sendmany` though there's no rush. The only missing feature afaik (see TODO) is adding labels to destination addresses. Additionally, `sendtoaddress` doesn't require JSON formatting of the address and destination, which arguably confuses new users. I could mimic that behavior as well.

title: [WIP] The ultimate send RPC
